questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding immune surveillance.

choices.text: Anti-CTLA-4 Ab is a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers
Mutation of tumour suppressor genes decreases antigen toxicity
PD1/PDL1 activation leading to tumour suppression
Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anti-CTLA-4 Ab is a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers

Explanation:

Anti-CTLA-4 antibody (Ab) is an emerging treatment in immunotherapy, especially in advanced cancers. It works by blocking the CTLA-4 receptor, enhancing T-cell activation and immune response against tumour cells.

 

 

Immune surveillance:

  • Immune surveillance refers to the immune system’s ability to detect and eliminate cancerous cells, thereby preventing cancer development and progression.
  • CTLA-4 (cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4) is a checkpoint protein that negatively regulates T-cell activation.
  • Immunotherapeutic agents, such as ipilimumab, target CTLA-4 to enhance T-cell activation, boosting the immune response against tumours and showing promising results in treating advanced cancers.

Mutations in tumour suppressor genes typically increase tumorigenicity and antigenicity (Option B), not decrease antigen toxicity.

PD1/PDL1 activation generally inhibits immune responses (Option C), leading to immune evasion by tumours, not suppression.

Binding of CD28 to CD80/86 enhances immune activation, not tolerance (Option D). Immune tolerance is more associated with inhibitory signals like CTLA-4.

questions.text: A young child presents with bleeding gums and bruising for the past two weeks. Bone marrow biopsy and flow cytometry have been performed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ALL: B Phenotype

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation, along with histopathological and flow cytometry findings, confirms a diagnosis of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) with a B-cell phenotype based on the following results:
  • Histopathological examination reveals lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm.


  • Flow cytometry analysis:
    • Image B: The lymphoblasts (indicated by red dots) expressing terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and the B-cell marker CD22.
    • Image C: The cells test positive for two other markers, CD10 and CD19, commonly found on pre-B lymphoblasts.

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

ALL is an acute-onset blood and bone marrow malignancy of B and T lymphoblasts characterised by the uncontrolled proliferation of abnormal and immature lymphocytes

Clinical features

  • Age: 2-8 years (Fast disease progression), adults: > 50 years.
  • Weight loss, Night sweats
  • Anemia: Easy fatigability and pallor
  • Bleeding: Epistaxis, easy bruising.
  • Leucocytopenia: Recurrent infections
  • Bone Marrow proliferation: Bone pain, sternal tenderness
  • Hepatosplenomegaly, Lymphadenopathy
  • CNS leukemia: Raised ICP, vomiting, and 6th nerve palsy
  • T cell tumors: Mediastinal and testicular mass.

Diagnosis

CBC is the first investigation performed while suspecting ALL:

  • Hemoglobin (Hb): Decreased, indicating normocytic normochromic anemia.
  • Hyperleukocytosis: TLC >100,000/µL can lead to leukostasis (more common in AML than ALL) with >20% Blasts.
  • Elderly Presentation: TLC often remains low throughout ALL.
  • Thrombocytopenia may be present.
 

Peripheral smear:

The smear shows a high percentage of lymphoblasts, which are larger than normal lymphocytes and have a high nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio. They often have a scant amount of cytoplasm and may exhibit nucleoli.

 

Bone Marrow aspiration shows blasts >20%.

  • It is also used to classify morphological types into L1, L2, and L3 in the FAB classification system.
 

FISH- Fluorescent in situ hybridization shows translocation of genes/chromosomes.

  • t(9:22) - ALL associated with the Philadelphia chromosome.
  • t(8:14) - Associated with Burkitt's leukemia
  • t(4:11)
  • t(1:19)
 

Flow cytometry:

  • CD10, also known as common acute lymphoblastic leukaemia antigen (CALLA), is a cell surface marker commonly used in the classification and diagnosis of leukaemias and lymphomas, particularly acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL).
  • B cell type - CD19+, CD79a+. (Option C)
  • T cell type - CD3+ (Option D ruled out)

 

Acute myeloid leukaemia (Option A) is a malignancy of hematopoietic progenitors caused by oncogenic mutations that prevent differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts. These blasts have delicate chromatin, two to four nucleoli, and more cytoplasm than lymphoblasts, often containing peroxidase-positive azurophilic granules. Auer rods, needle-like azurophilic granules, are also commonly present.

CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia) (Option B) is characterised by lymph node infiltration with small lymphocytes featuring condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm, along with larger activated lymphocytes forming proliferation centres, which are pathognomonic for CLL/SLL. The blood shows small lymphocytes and smudge cells, while the bone marrow, spleen, and liver are typically involved to varying degrees.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling and ataxia. Which among the following could likely be a cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

Explanation:

  • The case scenario of a 60-year-old man with scrotal swelling and ataxia is likely diagnosed as Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL), where lymphatic obstruction causes scrotal swelling, and CNS involvement leads to ataxia.
  • It is a type of cancer originating from lymphocytes and is characterized by the growth of lymphoid tissue.
  • Clinical features:
    • Asymptomatic Palpable Lymphadenopathy is the hallmark (neck, armpits, or groin).
    • Lymphadenopathy is not rapidly progressive.
    • B Symptoms (Fever, Night sweats, and Weight loss)
    • Extranodal involvement
      • Ileocecal region (abdominal pain or changes in bowel habits).
      • Lymphomatoid polyposis.
      • The oropharynx, especially Waldeyer's ring (sore throat or difficulty swallowing).
    • Bone marrow involvement (cytopenias-anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia).
    • Splenomegaly (abdominal discomfort and a sensation of fullness).

 

Hodgkin lymphoma

(Option B ruled out)

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

(Option C)

Age of presentation

Bimodal distribution peaks in young adults (15-35 years) and older adults (over 55).

More common in older adults but can occur at any age.

Localization

More often localised to a single axial group of nodes (cervical, mediastinal, para-aortic)

More frequent involvement of multiple peripheral nodes

Malignant cells

 

Reed-Sternberg cells (owl eye cells) - B cells - induce inflammation and fibrosis

Lymphoid cells - many subtypes - most are B cells than T cells

Mass composition

Inflammatory cells and fibrosis (reactive cells)

Lymphoid cells

Clinical

  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • B symptoms
  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are involved.

Spread

Contiguous (touching); rarely extranodal

Diffuse; often extranodal

Staging

  • Guides therapy
  • Radiation mainstay treatment

Limited importance

Leukemic phase

Doesn't occur

Occurs

 

Glioblastoma multiforme (Option A) is a type of brain tumour that arises from glial cells. It typically does not cause scrotal swelling or ataxia. The symptoms associated with glioblastoma multiforme are typically related to the location of the tumour within the brain.

Non-seminomatous germ cell tumours (Option D) are a type of testicular cancer that arise from germ cells in the testicles. While they can cause scrotal swelling, ataxia is not a typical presentation of this type of tumour.

questions.text: Which cell is the origin of chronic lymphocytic leukaemia / small lymphocytic lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Naive B cells

Explanation:

  • The cells of origin of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) and Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL) are mature B cells.

Genetics:

  • Trisomy 12, deletion 13q14, and others

Origin:

  • Post–germinal centre memory B cell or naive B Cells in the mantle zone of the lymph node (Option A)

Etiopathogenesis

  • Antiapoptotic protein BCL2 overexpression.
  • CLL cell growth depends on Bruton Tyrosine kinase (BTK) activity.
  • No association with radiation exposure

Clinical Presentation

  • Most common Leukemia in the elderly.
  • Frequently asymptomatic at diagnosis.
  • May present with fatigue, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, or infection due to immunosuppression.
  • Associated with autoimmune hemolytic anaemia- Spherocytes can be seen on peripheral smear
  • It can lead to hypogammaglobulinemia due to abnormal B cells, which impair normal antibody production.
  • Infection is the M/C/C of death in CLL

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • Absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) > 5000/mm3
  • Bone marrow lymphocytes >30%
  • Surface markers using flow cytometry were positive for CD5, CD23, CD19 CD20. CLL co-expresses both T cell ( CD5 ) and B cell ( CD20, CD19) markers

 

Mature T cells (Option B) can give rise to several cancers, including Peripheral T-cell lymphoma (PTCL), Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL), Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma (ATLL) (associated with HTLV-1), Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL), and T-cell prolymphocytic leukaemia (T-PLL).

Progenitor T cells (Option C) can give rise to cancers such as T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (T-ALL) and T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma (T-LBL). Both of these are aggressive hematologic malignancies that involve the malignant transformation of immature T cells (or T-cell precursors), characterized by rapid proliferation of immature T lymphocytes.

Granulocytes (Option D) can give rise to acute myelogenous leukaemia (AML), where immature myeloid cells, including granulocyte precursors, proliferate rapidly, and chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML), characterized by uncontrolled production of mature granulocytes due to the Philadelphia chromosome. Both cancers stem from the malignant transformation of myeloid progenitor cells.

questions.text: A patient with lytic lesions on the skull is suspected of a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Which of the following is a characteristic finding of electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Birbeck granules

Explanation:

  • A characteristic finding on electron microscopy in Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is the presence of Birbeck Granules.
  • These are rod-shaped, tennis racket-like structures that have a central linear striation.
  • They are considered to be specific ultrastructural markers for Langerhans cells.
  • These are thought to be derived from the endosomal compartment and are composed of a protein called langerin (CD207), a unique marker for Langerhans cells and is involved in antigen presentation and immune response regulation.

 

Histiocytes (Option A) are a type of immune cell that plays a key role in the body's defence mechanisms. They are specialized macrophages or dendritic cells found in tissues, where they function to engulf pathogens, dead cells, and foreign substances. Histiocytic disorders can give rise to cancers such as histiocytic sarcoma and Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

Eosinophils (Option C) are a type of white blood cell involved in immune responses, particularly in allergic reactions and parasitic infections. They can give rise to cancers such as eosinophilic leukaemia and eosinophilic lymphoma, which are rare disorders characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of eosinophils, leading to symptoms like organ infiltration, tissue damage, and inflammation.

Giant cells (Option D) are large, multinucleated cells that can arise in response to chronic inflammation or certain infections. They can be found in various cancers, such as giant cell tumours of bone (a benign but locally aggressive tumour) and osteoclast-like giant cell tumours in soft tissues. Additionally, giant cells are often seen in granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis and sarcoidosis, where they form part of the immune response.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy came with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the probable diagnosis, cell, and virus associated with the image given below?


	RS cell: Reed Stemberg cell
	HIV: Human immunodeficiency virus
	CMV: Cytomegalovirus
	EBV: Epstein–Barr virus
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hodgkin’s lymphoma, RS cell, EBV

Explanation:

  • The histopathological image reveals Reed-Sternberg cells, indicating Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL), which is associated with EBV (Epstein-Barr virus).

Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Etiology
  • M ore common in whites & Males.
  • Bimodal age distribution with peaks in the 20s and 80s.
  • It is not a part of AIDS-defining lymphoma.
  • Risk Factors:
    •  HIV infection is a major risk factor.
    • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). (Option C)

Reed-Sternberg (HRS) Cells

(Option C)
  • HRS cells are derived from the germinal centre or post-germinal centre B cells (mature B cells in peripheral lymph nodes).
  • Diagnostic of HL.
  • Large, with abundant cytoplasm, bilobed or multinucleated.
  • Typically positive for PAX-5, CD15, and CD30.

NF-κB Activation
  • Common in cHL, promoting RS cell growth and survival.
  • EBV+ Tumors: Express latent membrane protein-1 (LMP-1), which activates NF-κB.
  • EBV− Tumors: NF-κB activation may result from loss-of-function mutations in IκB or loss-of-function mutation of TNF-α–induced protein 3, both of which normally inhibit NF-κB.
  • NF-κB activation may rescue "crippled" B cells that can't express Ig, preventing apoptosis and enabling further mutations that form RS cells.

Immune Evasion
  • Genetic abnormalities at the PD-L1 locus on chromosome 9p24.1 lead to PD-L1 overexpression, which helps the tumour evade immune detection.

Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, RS cell, EBV (Option A): Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) is a diverse group of hematologic cancers marked by lymphoid tissue proliferation, often linked to HIV but not typically associated with Reed-Sternberg cells or EBV.

Kaposi sarcoma, Giant cell, HIV (Option B): Kaposi sarcoma is marked by the proliferation of spindle-shaped cells that express markers of both endothelial (vascular or lymphatic) and smooth muscle cells, and is linked to human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), but is not typically associated with Reed-Sternberg cells or EBV.

Infectious mononucleosis, RS cell, CMV (Option D): Infectious mononucleosis, a benign and self-limited lymphoproliferative disorder caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), is characterized histopathologically by atypical lymphocytes—large, irregularly shaped cells with abundant cytoplasm and prominent nuclei. It is not typically associated with Reed-Sternberg cells.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been complaining of fatigue for the past year. The examination revealed massive splenomegaly. His blood workup shows the presence of anemia, TLC 150,000/microL, and PBS shows 60% neutrophils, 6% basophils, 4% eosinophils, myeloblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. The myeloid-to-erythroid ratio was 18:1. Which of the following is the most sensitive investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) FISH and PCR

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation with massive splenomegaly, anaemia, and a markedly elevated TLC with myeloblasts, myelocytes, and basophils is highly suggestive of Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML), and the most sensitive test for diagnosing CML is FISH and PCR.

 

Investigations to find CML

CBC
  • Normal RBC + Elevated TLC + Elevated platelets

Peripheral smear
  • Left shift with predominant segmented neutrophils, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes.
  • College girl/garden party appearance.

Bone marrow aspirate
  • Increased Myeloid: Erythroid ratio.
  • Dwarf megakaryocytes.
  • Sea blue histiocytes (blue-coloured cytoplasm)
  • Pseudo Gaucher cells

NAP/LAP score

The leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is low in CML and can be used to differentiate it from other leukaemias, but it’s not the most sensitive test. (Option B ruled out)

FISH (IOC)
  • Confirms t(9:22) translocation.
  • Analysis to quantify Philadelphia chromosome-positive cells.
  • Estimates the tumour load.

PCR

  • To quantify BCR-ABL-1.
  • It can be a false negative or a false positive.
  • False negative: Early part of the disease.

 

Immunophenotyping (Option A) can be useful for characterising cell surface markers in hematologic malignancies, but it is not the most sensitive test for CML. It is more helpful in identifying acute leukaemias or lymphoproliferative disorders but does not directly detect the genetic mutation responsible for CML.

Flow cytometry (Option D) is primarily used to analyse the immunophenotype of hematologic cells and is useful for detecting acute leukaemias and lymphoproliferative disorders. However, it does not directly detect the Philadelphia chromosome or the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which are key to diagnosing CML.

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) β-2 microglobulin

Explanation:

  • In multiple myeloma, one of the most significant poor prognostic markers is β-2 microglobulin.
  • Elevated levels of β-2 microglobulin correlate with a higher tumour burden and more aggressive disease

Prognosis of Multiple Myeloma is determined by:

  • Durie-Salmon staging system (earlier)
  • International Staging System (ISS): Three-stage system to predict survival based on:
    • β2-microglobulin
    • Albumin levels

Calcium levels (Option B): Hypercalcemia is a common marker in multiple myeloma, but it is often a late-stage complication and does not directly indicate poor prognosis compared to β-2 microglobulin.

Serum creatinine (Option C), when elevated, indicates renal impairment, which is a common complication of multiple myeloma. While kidney function is important for prognosis, serum creatinine is not a prognosis indicator compared to β-2 microglobulin.

Protein levels (Option D) are commonly elevated and serve as disease markers, but they do not directly indicate a poor prognosis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal, with no immature cells. A lymph node biopsy showed diffuse effacement of the lymph node architecture and cells with an indented nucleus and prominent nucleolus that are atypical. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Follicular lymphoma

Explanation:

  • Given the lymphadenopathy, the findings on lymph node biopsy (indented nuclei, BCL2 positivity), and the normal blood counts (no immature cells), Follicular lymphoma is the most likely diagnosis.
  • Follicular lymphoma (FL) is a malignant neoplasm originating from germinal centre B-cells, characterised by the t(14;18) translocation leading to overexpression of BCL2.
  • Clinically, it presents with painless lymphadenopathy and may include systemic symptoms.
  • Histopathologically, FL exhibits a nodular growth pattern with centrocytes(Small cells with cleaved nuclei and scanty cytosol) and centroblasts(Larger cells with open nuclear chromatin and several nucleoli)
  • Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for CD10/19/20, BCL2, and BCL6, and negativity for CD5.
  • Management focuses on palliative approaches due to their indolent but incurable nature.

 

 

Burkitt lymphoma (Option B) is a type of B-cell lymphoma characterised by rapidly growing tumours, typically extranodal, most commonly in the abdomen or jaw. It often presents as large masses rather than just cervical lymphadenopathy. It has a "starry sky" pattern on histology due to macrophages phagocytosing apoptotic tumour cells, which was not noted in the biopsy here.

Mycosis fungoides (Option C) is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that primarily affects the skin and presents as patches, plaques, or tumours. It does not typically present with lymphadenopathy as a primary feature; its main involvement is in the skin rather than the lymph nodes.

Chronic myeloid leukemia (Option D) is a myeloproliferative disorder that is marked by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22) translocation), which leads to the production of the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

questions.text:
A patient with cervical lymphadenopathy has a positive t(11;14) translocation. Which of the following markers should be used to confirm the diagnosis?

A. CD10

B. CD200

C. SOX11

D. Cyclin D1
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) C, D

Explanation:

  • The t(11;14) translocation is a characteristic feature of mantle cell lymphoma.
  • Immunohistochemistry for Cyclin D1 is crucial to confirm the diagnosis, as it is overexpressed in mantle cell lymphoma due to this translocation.
  • SOX11 is another marker commonly expressed in mantle cell lymphoma and can help in diagnosis.

Neoplasm

Cell of origin

Description

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

Germinal/post-germinal center B cells
  • Most common NHL.
  • Associated with BCL6 gene rearrangement
  • If CLL transforms into DLBCL, it is called Richter's Syndrome.

Hairy cell leukemia

Memory B cells
  • More common in boys.
  • BRAF V600E Mutation +
  • It presents with massive splenomegaly affecting the red pulp of the spleen.

Mantle cell lymphoma

Naive B cell
  • Translocation t(11:14).
  • Associated with GIT polyps.
  • Cyclin D1 and SOX11 +ve

Mycosis Fungoides

Helper T cells
  • Cutaneous T-cell NHL.
  • Presents with erythema and pruritus.
  • If it affects the blood vessels, it is known as Sezary syndrome.

CD10, also known as CALLA (Common Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Antigen), is a cell surface marker commonly used in the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma and Burkitt lymphoma, as well as other B-cell lymphomas. However, CD10 is not typically expressed in mantle cell lymphoma.

CD200 is more commonly associated with other lymphoproliferative disorders, such as chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL), rather than mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text:
Which of the following is a possible explanation for the presence of pancytopenia as indicated by the blood examination results?

A. Megaloblastic anemia

B. Hairy cell leukemia

C. MDS with hypocellular BM

D. APML
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A, B, C

Explanation:

  • Megaloblastic anaemia is caused by impaired DNA synthesis, leading to the production of abnormally large and immature red blood cells (megaloblasts). Pancytopenia occurs due to reduced production of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.
  • Hairy cell leukaemia is a rare form of chronic lymphocytic leukaemia characterized by abnormal B lymphocytes with hair-like projections on their surface. It can lead to pancytopenia by infiltrating the bone marrow with these atypical cells, which disrupt normal blood cell production.
  • MDS with hypocellular bone marrow: Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of disorders marked by ineffective blood cell production. In some cases, MDS leads to a hypocellular bone marrow, where the number of blood-forming cells is lower than usual, resulting in pancytopenia due to a reduction in the production of all types of blood cells.

Causes of pancytopenia in hypocellular marrow:

  • Hypocellular MDS
  • Some Lymphomas and ALL
  • Copper deficiency
  • Acquired aplastic anemia

Causes of pancytopenia in cellular bone marrow:

  • Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS)
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Myelofibrosis
  • Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
  • Sarcoidosis, HIV, Brucellosis,Leishmaniasis
  • Hypersplenism
  • Bone marrow lymphoma

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL)?

choices.text: Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

Explanation:

  • Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL) typically has a more favourable prognosis compared to classical Hodgkin lymphoma (HL).
  • It is usually EBV negative, CD30 negative, and CD20 positive, characteristic features of NLPHL. However, it does not generally have a poorer prognosis than classical HL.

 

Subtypes and features of Hodgkin’s lymphoma:

Subtype

Morphology and Immunophenotype

Typical Clinical Features

Nodular Sclerosis
  • Frequent lacunar cells and occasional diagnostic Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells.
  • Background infiltrate includes T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, and plasma cells.
  • Fibrous bands divide cellular areas into nodules.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+; usually EBV negative.
  • Most common subtype, typically stage I or II with mediastinal involvement.
  • Equal occurrence in males and females.
  • Common in young adults.

Mixed Cellularity
  • Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells.
  • Background infiltrate rich in T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, and plasma cells.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+; 70% EBV positive.
  • More than 50% present as stage III or IV.
  • More common in males.
  • Biphasic incidence peaks in young adults and those >55 years.

Lymphocyte-Rich
  • Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells. Background infiltrate rich in T lymphocytes.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+; 40% EBV positive.
  • Uncommon, more frequent in males.
  • Typically seen in older adults.

Lymphocyte Depletion
  • Reticular variant with numerous RS cells and few background reactive cells.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+, most EBV positive.
  • Rare, more common in older men, HIV-infected individuals, and low-income regions.
  • Often presents with advanced disease.

Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant
  • Frequent L&H (popcorn) cell variants in a background of follicular dendritic cells and reactive B cells.
  • RS cells: CD20+, CD15−, CD30−; EBV negative.
  • Uncommon, typically in young males.
  • Presents with cervical/axillary lymphadenopathy.
  • Rarely involves the mediastinum.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 10-year-old boy with Down syndrome who presents with a mediastinal mass (SVC-like syndrome), based on the provided bone marrow histology shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia)

Explanation:

  • Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) is the most common leukemia and cancer in children, often seen in patients with Down syndrome.
  • It is a clonal malignancy where lymphoblasts, early lymphoid precursors, proliferate abnormally, replacing normal hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow in ALL shows lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm, which are characteristic of lymphoblastic leukemia.
  • Precursor B-cell ALL shows large purple malignant lymphoblasts on bone marrow aspirate smears.
  • Normal lymphoblasts mature into B-cells or T-cells that fight infections, but in ALL, they fail to mature properly.
  • T-cell ALL may present as a mediastinal mass, potentially causing superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome.
  • Both peripheral blood and bone marrow in ALL show increased lymphoblasts.
  • ALL has a poorer prognosis in adults compared to children.

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

  • Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolations
  • They contain fat (Oil Red O Positive)
  • Hand mirror-shaped cells

 

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

  • Blasts ≥ 20%
  • Myeloblasts with AuerRods

 

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL):

  • Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cell): Due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation
  • Convent Girl Appearance: Lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

  • Leukocytosis
  • Cell Types: Neutrophils( multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

 

 

 

AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia) (Option A) is a blood and bone marrow cancer primarily affecting adults caused by the uncontrolled proliferation of myeloblasts (immature white blood cells). It is characterised by an abundance of abnormal cells that fail to mature into healthy blood cells, leading to symptoms like infections, anaemia, and easy bleeding.

Aplastic Anemia (Option B) is a serious condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells, leading to low blood counts and symptoms like easy bruising, heavy menstrual bleeding, shortness of breath, fatigue, and frequent infections. It can be inherited or acquired, with acquired cases often linked to immune system dysfunction.

Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia (JMML) (Option D) is a rare blood cancer in young children, characterised by abnormal development of monocytes and myelocytes (types of white blood cells). Treatment often involves chemotherapy followed by a bone marrow transplant. Unlike ALL, JMML does not typically present with lymphoblasts.

questions.text: All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of tumours associated with which of the following genetic aberrations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) PML-RARA

Explanation:

  • All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is specifically used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL), which is associated with the genetic fusion of PML (promyelocytic leukaemia gene) and RARA (retinoic acid receptor alpha) genes. The fusion disrupts the normal differentiation of promyelocytes, and ATRA helps reverse this block by promoting differentiation.

 

M3 AML/ Acute promyelocytic leukaemia:

  • Genetics:
    • t(15:17) translocation causes PML-RARA (retinoic acid receptor alpha) fusion protein formation.
    • Blocks promyelocyte → myelocyte maturation.
    • Diagnosis of choice: FISH
  • Smear findings:
    • Increased promyelocytes.
    • Auer Rods: Fused granules in promyelocytes
    • Faggot Cells: Auer rods with a crisscross pattern.
  • Laboratory:
    • Low haemoglobin and platelets.
    • > 20% blasts on peripheral and bone marrow smear
    • Stain: PAS +
    • CD markers: CD 13, 33 +
  • Complication: Disseminated intravascular coagulation therefore, chemotherapy is not recommended.
  • Treatment:
    • ATRA (All-trans-retinoic-acid) + As2O3 (arsenic trioxide)
    • Best prognosis among all AML.

BCR-ABL (Option B) fusion gene is characteristic of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). The treatment for CML typically involves tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib) rather than ATRA.

cMYC (Option C) is an oncogene often implicated in Burkitt lymphoma and other cancers, but it is not treated with ATRA. Treatment for cMYC-related tumours typically involves chemotherapy and targeted therapy based on the specific malignancy.

RUNX1-ETO (Option D) fusion gene is associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), but it does not respond to ATRA treatment. Treatment for AML often includes chemotherapy and other agents.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man has presented with chronic lower back pain, fatigue, and headaches for the last few weeks. On examination, he has pallor and bony tenderness. Lab investigations revealed an increased ESR, and his skull radiograph revealed several punched-out lytic lesions. Which of the following is the best investigation for this patient among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Serum electrophoresis showing IgG

Explanation:

  • The patient's pain, fatigue, multiple punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray, and elevated ESR suggest Multiple myeloma.
  • The best investigation is serum electrophoresis, which detects monoclonal immunoglobulins, such as IgG, confirming the diagnosis and quantifying the abnormal proteins.

 

Incorrect Options:

Serum levels of CA 15-3 (Option B): CA 15-3 is a tumour marker primarily used for monitoring breast cancer.

Whole-body scan (Option C): While imaging studies such as whole-body scans may be useful in assessing the extent of multiple myeloma involvement, they are not typically the initial investigation for diagnosis.

CT head with contrast (Option D) is not necessary for multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male underwent a bone marrow examination, which revealed the presence of the following findings, as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Multiple myeloma

Explanation:

  • Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy characterised by the uncontrolled proliferation of clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow.

Bone Marrow Examination:

  • Presence of ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow.
  • Atypical plasma cells with features such as binucleation, prominent nucleoli, and perinuclear hof (Golgi clearing).

Serum and Urine Electrophoresis:

  • Detection of monoclonal (M) protein in serum or urine (commonly IgG or IgA).
  • Free light chains may be detected in urine (Bence Jones proteins).

CRAB Criteria (End-Organ Damage):

  • Calcium elevation (hypercalcemia).
  • Renal dysfunction (elevated creatinine).
  • Anaemia (normocytic, normochromic).
  • Bone lesions (osteolytic lesions on skeletal imaging).


Incorrect Options:

ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia) (Option B) is characterised by increased bone marrow and peripheral blood lymphoblasts but lacks the plasma cell morphology seen in multiple myeloma.

Tuberculosis (Option C) of the bone marrow usually shows granulomas with caseous necrosis, not plasma cells.

Sickle Cell Disease (Option D): Bone marrow findings in sickle cell disease may show erythroid hyperplasia and abnormal erythrocytes, but plasma cells are not a feature.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with Down syndrome presents with mediastinal mass (presenting as SVC-like syndrome), and Peripheral blood and bone marrow have increased lymphoblasts. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis is based on the presence of increased lymphoblasts in peripheral blood and bone marrow, along with a mediastinal mass causing SVC-like syndrome, a characteristic feature of T-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (ALL).
  • The strong association with Down syndrome further supports the diagnosis.
  • Common in children, with a worse prognosis in adults.
  • T-cell ALL often presents with a mediastinal mass.
  • Immunophenotyping: TdT+ (a marker of pre-T and pre-B cells), CD10+ (a marker of pre-B cells).

Incorrect Options:

Acute Myeloblastic Leukemia (AML) (Option A) typically presents with symptoms such as fatigue, recurrent infections, bleeding tendencies, and bone pain. It is less commonly associated with hepatosplenomegaly and sternal tenderness.

Chronic Lymphoblastic Leukemia (CLL) (Option B) usually occurs in older individuals and is characterised by lymphocytosis, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. It is less likely to present with hepatomegaly, sternal tenderness, and petechiae in a 10-year-old patient.

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) (Option D) typically presents in adults and is characterised by an elevated white blood cell count, splenomegaly, and a characteristic genetic abnormality called the Philadelphia chromosome. It is less common in children and may not present with the described symptoms.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 5-year-old boy who has weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in his jaw area? CBC results indicate anaemia and lymphocytosis. The image below shows biopsy findings from the swelling.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Burkitt lymphoma

Explanation:

  • The histopathological picture is of a Classical Burkitt Lymphoma involving a lymph node.
  • The most characteristic finding is a “starry sky” pattern.
  • At high-power magnification, the neoplastic cells are of intermediate size, similar to the size of benign histiocyte nuclei.
  • The neoplastic cells have round nuclear contours, multiple nucleoli, frequent mitoses, and basophilic cytoplasm. Macrophages with engulfed pyknotic nuclei and nuclear debris are also present.

 

Burkitt's lymphoma

Aspects

Description

Definition

An aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterised by the proliferation of mature B-cells.

Epidemiology
  • Endemic (African) form: Common in children, associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection.
  • Sporadic form: Worldwide distribution, more common in children and young adults.
  • Immunodeficiency-related: Often seen in HIV/AIDS patients.

Etiology
  • Strong association with EBV (especially in the endemic form).
  • Translocations involving the MYC gene (chromosome 8).

Genetic Abnormality
  • t(8;14): MYC gene translocated next to the IgH locus (most common).
  • t(2;8) or t(8;22): Less common, involving MYC and Ig light chain loci.

Clinical Features
  • Endemic form: Presents with jaw or facial bone tumours.
  • Sporadic form: Often involves the abdomen (e.g., ileum, cecum) and may cause bowel obstruction.
  • Systemic symptoms: Fever, night sweats, weight loss.

Pathology
  • Histology: "Starry-sky" appearance due to numerous apoptotic cells and macrophages.
  • Tumor cells are medium-sized with round nuclei, coarse chromatin, and high mitotic activity.

Immunophenotype
  • Positive for CD19, CD20 (B-cell markers), and CD10.
  • Expresses surface IgM.
  • High proliferation index (Ki-67 > 95%).

Diagnosis
  • Biopsy: Histological examination showing "starry-sky" appearance.
  • Cytogenetics: Detection of MYC translocations.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Positive for B-cell markers (CD19, CD20).

Prognosis
  • Highly aggressive but potentially curable with prompt treatment.
  • Favorable response to chemotherapy in many cases.

Treatment
  • Chemotherapy: Intensive regimens like cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and methotrexate (CODOX-M).
  • CNS prophylaxis: Methotrexate or cytarabine.
  • Supportive care for tumour lysis syndrome.

Complications
  • Risk of tumour lysis syndrome due to rapid tumour breakdown.
  • It may progress to involve bone marrow or CNS if untreated.

Differential Diagnosis
  • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.
  • Other high-grade B-cell lymphomas.
  • Lymphoblastic lymphoma.
  • Hodgkin lymphoma (rarely resembles).

Kikuchi disease (Option A) is a subacute necrotising lymphadenopathy affecting young adults, predominantly women, especially in Japan and neighbouring Asian countries. It presents with painless lymphadenopathy, moderate fever, chills, myalgia, sore throat, and skin rashes. Histopathology reveals necrotising lymphadenitis with histiocyte proliferation and reactive germinal centres.

Infectious mononucleosis (Option B) presents with a triad of fever, pharyngitis, and cervical or generalised lymphadenopathy. Histopathology reveals Paracortical hyperplasia with a mottled ("moth-eaten") lymph node architecture.

Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) (Option C) is characterised by a heterogeneous cellularity comprising a minority of specific neoplastic cells—the Hodgkin cells, the Reed-Sternberg cells, and a majority of reactive non-neoplastic cells.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with anaemia and hepatosplenomegaly. A peripheral smear showed teardrop cells, nucleated RBCs, and giant abnormal platelets. A biopsy showed marrow fibrosis and a few characteristics, as given below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Primary myelofibrosis

Explanation:

  • Primary myelofibrosis (PMF) is a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm characterised by the development of extensive marrow fibrosis, which impairs normal hematopoiesis.
  • This fibrosis is driven by the inappropriate release of fibrogenic factors, such as platelet-derived growth factor and TGF-β, from neoplastic megakaryocytes.
  • Clinically, PMF presents with progressive anaemia, splenomegaly, and symptoms like fatigue and weight loss.

 

 

WHO diagnostic criteria:

Major criteria:

  • Megakaryocyte proliferation and atypia, usually with reticulin or collagen fibrosis.
  • Not meeting WHO criteria for BCR-ABL1 + CML, PV, ET, MDS, or other myeloid neoplasm.
  • Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation or in the absence of these mutations, presence of other clonal markers, or absence of minor reactive BM reticulin fibrosis.

Minor criteria:

  • Leukocytosis ≥ 11 × 109/L.
  • Increased Serum Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH).
  • Anaemia is not attributed to another condition.
  • Palpable Splenomegaly.

 

Polycythemia vera (Option A): Given that the patient presents with anaemia, the diagnosis is unlikely to be polycythemia vera.

Essential thrombocythemia (Option B): In Essential thrombocythemia, patients usually present erythromelalgia and elevated platelet count, and there is an absence of marrow fibrosis.

Chronic myeloid leukaemia (Option D): Though CML presents with anaemia and splenomegaly, bone marrow aspirate in CML is likely to show dwarf megakaryocyte and characteristic garden party appearance.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and multiple ecchymoses. Lab investigations show:

Haemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL

Platelet count: 12,000 platelets/mm3

Total leucocyte count: 52,000 cells/mm3 with 83% blasts, as seen below.

The blasts are CD33 +ve. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acute Myeloid Leukemia

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and multiple ecchymoses with anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis with 83% blast, which is CD33+ve, and peripheral smear showing myeloblasts is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia.
  • AML arises due to genetic mutations in hematopoietic stem cells, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloblasts in the bone marrow, resulting in marrow failure.
  • Patients often present with pancytopenia-related symptoms, including easy bruising (due to thrombocytopenia), fatigue (due to anaemia), and infections (due to leukopenia with dysfunctional blasts).

 

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (Option B): In ALL, the lymphoblasts are CD33-ve and myeloperoxidase-ve.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (Option C): Smudge cells characteristic of CLL are CD33-ve, CD20+ve, and CD5+ve.

Myelodysplastic Syndrome (Option D) is a heterogeneous group of hematologic neoplasms classically described as a clonal disorder of hematopoietic stem cells leading to dysplasia and ineffective hematopoiesis in the bone marrow. Some patients with MDS may have a transformation into acute myeloid leukemia.

questions.text: What is the type of cell from which the cell displayed below originates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) B cells

Explanation:

  • B cells express CD19, CD20, and CD21 markers.
  • When activated, they differentiate into plasma cells, which have an eccentric nucleus, basophilic cytoplasm, and a perinuclear halo (indicative of the Golgi apparatus involved in antibody production).
  • Plasma cells secrete immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, etc.), essential for humoral immunity.

 

NK (Natural Killer) (Option A) cells are innate immune cells. NK cells are lymphocytes that arise from the same common lymphoid progenitor that gives rise to T lymphocytes and B lymphocytes.

CD4 (Option B) and CD8 (Option D) are expressed on distinct T-cell subsets and act as coreceptors during T-cell activation.CD4 is expressed in 50% to 60% of T cells, whereas CD8 is expressed in about 40% of T cells. The CD4- and CD8-expressing T cells—called CD4+ and CD8+ cells, respectively

questions.text:
Which CD markers are typically positive in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL)?

.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CD19, CD20, CD23, CD5:

Explanation:

In Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL), the hallmark immunophenotype is:

  • B-cell markers: CD19, CD20, CD23
  • Aberrant co-expression of T-cell marker: CD5 (this is unusual for B-cells and is a diagnostic clue)
  • CLL is a mature B-cell neoplasm → expresses typical B-cell surface antigens (CD19, CD20, CD23).
  • Uniquely, it abnormally expresses CD5, which is normally a T-cell marker, this feature helps distinguish CLL from other B-cell leukemias/lymphomas.

Incorrect Options:

CD3, CD5, CD8 (Option A): T-cell markers (CD8 = cytotoxic T cells), not CLL.

CD10, CD19, CD22 (Option B): seen in precursor B-cell ALL (CD10 - CALLA antigen), not mature CLL.

CD13, CD33, CD117 (Option D): myeloid lineage markers (seen in AML), not lymphoid.

questions.text: 2-year-old with fever, lymphadenopathy and H&E has hallmark cells. The diagnosis of anaplastic large cell lymphoma was made. Most likely translocation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - t(2;5):

Explanation:

Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma (ALCL) is most often associated with the t(2;5) translocation.

  • t(2;5) → creates the NPM-ALK fusion gene
    • NPM - nucleophosmin (chromosome 5)
    • ALK - anaplastic lymphoma kinase (chromosome 2)
  • This fusion leads to constitutive activation of ALK tyrosine kinase, driving uncontrolled cell growth.
  • ALCL histology shows hallmark cells, large pleomorphic cells with horseshoe- or kidney-shaped nuclei and abundant cytoplasm.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

  • t(8;14) (Option A): Seen in Burkitt lymphoma. MYC gene on chromosome 8 translocates to Ig heavy chain locus on chromosome 14 → MYC overexpression. It is a very aggressive B-cell lymphoma; common in children in malaria-endemic areas.
  • t(8;22) (Option B): Variant of Burkitt lymphoma involving MYC and Ig lambda light chain locus (chromosome 22).
  • t(14;18) (Option D): Seen in Follicular lymphoma. BCL2 gene (chromosome 18) translocates to Ig heavy chain locus (chromosome 14) → BCL2 overexpression → apoptosis inhibition. It usually has an indolent course.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with bleeding manifestations. The peripheral smear shows the presence of the cells shown below. Which of the following is the most common chromosomal abnormality seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) t(15;17)

Explanation:

This patient's history of 68 year old man with bleeding manifestations and Auer-rods on blood smear suggests disseminated intravascular coagulation secondary to acute promyelocytic leukaemia associated with t(15:17) translocation.

M3 AML/ Acute promyelocytic leukaemia:

  • Genetics:
    • t(15:17) translocation causes PML-RARA (retinoic acid receptor alpha) fusion protein formation.
    • Blocks promyelocyte → myelocyte maturation.
    • Diagnosis of choice: FISH
  • Smear findings:
    • Increased promyelocytes.
    • Auer Rods: Fused granules in promyelocytes
    • Faggot Cells: Auer rods with a crisscross pattern.
  • Laboratory:
    • Low haemoglobin and platelets.
    • > 20% blasts on peripheral and bone marrow smear
    • Stain: PAS +
    • CD markers: CD 13, 33 +
  • Complication: Disseminated intravascular coagulation; therefore, chemotherapy is not recommended.
  • Treatment:
    • ATRA (All-trans-retinoic-acid) + As2O3 (arsenic trioxide)
    • Best prognosis among all AML.

 

Incorrect Options:

t(8;21) (Option A): AML with maturation (FAB M2); often associated with large myeloblasts and abundant Auer rods, but not the classic multiple “faggot cell” picture of APL. It is associated with Chloroma.

t(14;18) (Option C): Follicular lymphoma; involves BCL2 gene rearrangement, unrelated to AML.

inv(16) (Option D): Associated with AML with abnormal eosinophils (FAB M4Eo), not APL.

questions.text: A 70 year old male presents with low back ache and progressive pallor. On work up: KFT is deranged, LFT is normal with normal level of albumin and gamma globulin increased disproportionately. X-ray spine shows multiple lytic lesions. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Multiple myeloma:

  • Multiple myeloma is a malignancy of plasma cells, a type of white blood cell that produces antibodies. It is characterized by the presence of abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow, which can lead to bone destruction and the release of monoclonal (abnormal) immunoglobulins or light chains into the bloodstream. The clinical presentation of low back ache, progressive pallor (anemia), deranged kidney function tests (KFT), disproportionately increased gamma globulin levels, and lytic lesions on X-ray spine are all consistent with multiple myeloma.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - MGUS (Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance): MGUS is a benign condition where a small amount of abnormal plasma cells produce a monoclonal protein (usually immunoglobulin) in the blood. It is generally asymptomatic and does not cause significant organ damage. The patient in the scenario has more severe symptoms and findings that are not typical for MGUS.

Option C - Immunoglobulin Light Chain Amyloidosis (AL): AL amyloidosis is a rare condition where abnormal light chain proteins are deposited as amyloid in various organs, including the kidneys. This can lead to organ dysfunction. While AL amyloidosis can cause kidney involvement and abnormal levels of light chains, the lytic bone lesions seen on X-ray and the disproportionately increased gamma globulin levels are not characteristic of AL amyloidosis.

Option D - Solitary Plasmacytoma: Solitary plasmacytoma is a localized tumor of plasma cells that typically presents as a single mass in bone or soft tissue. It is less likely in this case because the patient has multiple lytic lesions on X-ray spine, which indicates widespread bone involvement. Solitary plasmacytoma typically doesn't show this pattern of multiple bone lesions.

questions.text: Which gene mutation is most commonly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Burkitt's lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is strongly associated with a translocation involving the C-myc oncogene.

 

Burkitt’s lymphoma.

  • Burkitt's lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma associated with the translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8, t(8:14).
  • It has three primary subtypes:
  1. Endemic Burkitt's lymphoma: Commonly affects children in malaria-endemic areas of Africa, often presenting with tumours in the jaw or facial bones.
  2. Sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma: More frequently seen in non-endemic regions and usually involving the ileocaecal region and peritoneum.
  3. Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma: Found in patients with conditions such as HIV/AIDS or other forms of immunodeficiency.

P-21 (Option B):
P-21 (CDKN1A) is a cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor that regulates the cell cycle by inhibiting cyclin-CDK complexes. It plays a role in cell cycle arrest but is not primarily associated with Burkitt's lymphoma.

Rb (Option C):
The Retinoblastoma (Rb) gene is a tumor suppressor that controls the G1/S checkpoint of the cell cycle. Its mutations are primarily associated with retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, not Burkitt's lymphoma.

p53 (Option D):
The p53 gene (TP53) is a tumor suppressor involved in DNA repair and apoptosis. While TP53 mutations are found in various cancers, they are not the characteristic mutation seen in Burkitt's lymphoma.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with low hemoglobin, platelet count of 25,000/mm3, and raised PT and APTT. The peripheral smear image is shown below. Which of the following fusion genes is likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - PML-RARA:

  • The given image shows faggot cells containing Auer rods, which is a characteristic feature of Acute myeloid leukemia M3. In AML M3, t(15:17) - PML-RARA fusion gene is affected.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not affected in AML M3.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, abdominal pain, and WBC count > 50,000/mm3. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - t(9;22):

  • The given clinical features are suggestive of chronic myeloid leukemia, and the genetic abnormality associated with it is translocation of t(9;22).

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not associated with CML.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with elevated calcium levels, increased serum creatinine levels, and decreased hemoglobin. Electrophoresis reveals a monoclonal spike. Her immunofixation test findings are given below. Which of the following best describes her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) MM with increased IgM

Explanation:

  • Multiple myeloma is characterized by a monoclonal spike on electrophoresis, and the immunofixation test revealed increased IgM levels (a distinct band can be seen, whereas the smear pattern without any band formation above IgG is insignificant)

Serum Protein Electrophoresis in Multiple Sclerosis:

 

  • The gamma (Ig) will increase and show a spike an M spike - monoclonal or myeloma spike
  • Immunofixation - will tell the type of immunoglobulin

Immunofixation of MM with increased IgG

Incorrect Options:

MM with increased IgG (Option A): Smear pattern without any bands, so its not IgG

MM with increased IgA (Option C) : No protein fixation, so its not IgA

MGUS (Option D): In MGUS, gammaglobulins levels are <3gm/dL

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation of choice for CML?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) FISH

Explanation:

  • Fluorescence in situ hybridisation (FISH) is the choice of investigation for detecting the Philadelphia chromosome in CML.
  • It makes a cytogenetic analysis of the Philadelphia chromosome.
  • The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 [t(9;22)(q34;q11)], or detection of the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene on mRNA, confirms the diagnosis of CML.

Diagnosis of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

CBC
  • Normal RBC + Elevated TLC + Elevated platelets

Peripheral smear
  • Left shift with predominant segmented neutrophils, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes.
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to non-uniform appearance (every cell appears different).

Bone marrow aspirate
  • Increased Myeloid: Erythroid ratio.
  • Dwarf megakaryocytes.
  • Sea blue histiocytes (blue-coloured cytoplasm)
  • Pseudo Gaucher cells

The image shows Pseudo-Gaucher cells

NAP (Neutrophil Alkaline Phosphatase)/LAP score (Leukocyte Alkaline Phosphatase)

(Option A ruled out)
  • Decreased

FISH (IOC)

(Option B)

  • Confirms t(9:22) translocation.
  • Analysis to quantify Philadelphia chromosome-positive cells.
  • Estimates the tumour load.

The image shows BCR-ABL gene fusion (red + green) in fluorescence in-situ hybridisation (FISH; the ABL gene is red, and the BCR gene is green).

PCR

  • To quantify BCR-ABL-1
  • It can be a false negative or false positive
  • False negative: Early part of the disease

 

Karyotyping (Option C) examines chromosomes to detect abnormalities like Down syndrome or the Philadelphia chromosome in CML. While it can identify chromosomal abnormalities, it is less sensitive than FISH for detecting the Philadelphia chromosome.

Reciprocal translocation (Option D) is a chromosomal abnormality where segments of two chromosomes are exchanged, such as the Philadelphia chromosome in CML. It results in the BCR-ABL fusion gene, detectable by FISH or karyotyping, but is not an independent diagnostic test.

questions.text: Mark the incorrect statement regarding Hodgkin Lymphoma:

choices.text: Reed Sternberg cells are of B-cell origin
Nodular sclerosing is the most commonsubtype and involves mediastinum
CD 15, 30 Positivity in Reed Sternberg cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Waldeyer's ring is involved:

  • Waldeyer's ring is usually involved in non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Hodgkin Lymphoma usually involves the Cervical, Axillary, and Inguinal lymph nodes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Reed Sternberg cells are of B-cell origin: T Hodgkin’s lymphoma is type B-cell lymphoma involving the Reed-Sternberg cells.

Option B - Nodular sclerosing is the most common subtype and involves mediastinum: Nodular sclerosing is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma and involves the mediastinum.

Option D - CD 15, 30 Positivity in Reed Sternberg cells: Reed Sternberg cells are CD-15, 30 positive.

questions.text: A patient with elevated calcium and normal alkaline phosphatase undergoes a skull X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Multiple myeloma

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of a patient with elevated calcium, normal alkaline phosphatase, and osteolytic lesions on a skull X-ray suggests Multiple Myeloma.
  • It is a plasma cell neoplasm associated with (Mnemonic: CRAB features with immune abnormalities)
    • C - Hypercalcemia
    • R - Renal failure
    • A - Anaemia
    • B - Lytic bone lesions, and
    • Immune abnormalities.

Antibodies in Multiple Myeloma:

Monoclonal Immunoglobulins

Free Light Chains
  • IgG: Most common (55% of patients).
  • IgA: Seen in 25% of cases.
  • IgM, IgD, IgE: Less common.
  • Often produced in excess, these are called Bence Jones proteins.
  • It can cause myeloma kidney (renal disease).

Pathogenesis of Multiple Myeloma:

  • There are 3 main cytogenetic abnormalities seen in MM.
    • Deletion of chromosome 13q (also seen in CLL).
    • Translocation t (11;14) (also seen in mantle cell lymphoma).
    • Deletion of chromosome 17p (TP53).
    • IL-6 is essential for plasma cell growth, and its elevated levels are linked to poor prognosis.

Clinical features:

  • It is seen in patients 60-70 years of age.
  • Increased osteoclastic activity leads to bone resorption hypercalcemia and lytic punched-out lesions.
  • Decreased osteoblastic activity (Normal or ↓ ALP levels).

Multiple Punched-out Osteolytic Lesions on the Lateral Skull Radiograph in a patient with Multiple Myeloma

 

Grave’s disease (Option A) is an autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism, characterised by an overactive thyroid gland. It results in symptoms like weight loss, heat intolerance, tremors, and bulging eyes (exophthalmos). It is caused by autoantibodies that stimulate the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor. It involves thyroid hormone imbalance and does not typically cause hypercalcemia or specific bone lesions on X-ray.

Paget’s disease (Option B) is a bone disorder marked by abnormal bone remodelling, leading to enlarged and weakened bones. It causes bone pain, deformities, and fractures with elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. It typically causes elevated alkaline phosphatase due to abnormal bone remodelling.


Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) (Option D) is a bone marrow cancer characterised by excessive white blood cell production and the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome. It typically causes fatigue, weight loss, and splenomegaly but does not present with hypercalcemia or lytic bone lesions.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male complains of lower back pain with a 1-1.5 mm osteolytic lesion at the T10 vertebra. Histopathological findings are given below. Which of the following options is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: Decreased Calcium levels in the blood

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Presence of Bence-Jones proteinuria

Explanation:

  • The scenario describing lower back pain with a 1-1.5 mm osteolytic lesion at the T10 vertebra and a histopathological image showing intracytoplasmic inclusions (Russell bodies) suggests Multiple Myeloma, which is characterised by the presence of Bence-Jones proteinuria.
  • It is caused by increased antibody production.
  • It is a plasma cell neoplasm associated with (Mnemonic: CRAB features with immune abnormalities)
    • C - Hypercalcemia (Option D ruled out)
    • R - Renal failure
    • A - Anaemia
    • B - Lytic bone lesions, and
    • Immune abnormalities.
  • The cells produce excess free light chains, either alongside complete immunoglobulins or independently. (Option C ruled out)
  • Due to their small size, free light chains (Bence Jones proteins) can pass through the glomeruli of the kidneys and appear in the urine. This is a diagnostic marker for multiple myeloma.

Inclusion Bodies Seen In Multiple Myeloma

Russel bodies:
  • Location: Intracytoplasmic
  • Composition:
    • Eosinophilic
    • Round
    • Dilated endoplasmic reticulum cisternae filled with condensed immunoglobulin.

.

Dutcher bodies
  • Location: Intranuclear.
  • Composition: Globular inclusions containing accumulated immunoglobulin.

Plasma Cell Variants In Multiple Myeloma

Mott cells

  • Contain Grape-like cytoplasmic droplets.
  • Composition: Inclusion bodies, fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules.

Flame cells
  • Appearance: Fiery red cytoplasm.
  • Cause: High concentration of immunoglobulin as bright red granules within the cytoplasm.
  • Often seen in IgA subtype myeloma.

 

 

Rouleaux formation
  • High levels of M protein in the blood cause red cells to stick to one another in linear arrays in smears, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation. (Option B ruled out)
  • It is also seen in s lupus erythematosus and early HIV infection.

​​ ​​ ​​ ​​ ​​

questions.text: Which among the following is associated with Cryoglobulinemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hepatitis C infection

Explanation:

Hepatitis C infection is associated with Cryoglobulinemia.

Cryoglobulinemia:

  • Cryoglobulins are proteins that precipitate from serum or plasma at low temperatures (<37°C).
  • They can be a mixture of immunoglobulin and complement components or immunoglobulins alone.
  • They deposit in medium and large-sized blood vessels throughout the body, causing endothelial injury and end-organ damage known as cryoglobulinemia.
  • It is often associated with
    • Hepatitis C virus infection
    • Hepatitis B virus infection
    • HIV
    • Autoimmune diseases ( mainly SLE and Sjogren’s syndrome)
    • Lymphoproliferative disorders.

Ovarian cancer (Option B) is a type of cancer that begins in the ovaries (female reproductive organs). It often goes undiagnosed in the early stages due to vague symptoms like abdominal bloating, pelvic pain, and early satiety. Risk factors include age, family history, and genetic mutations (such as BRCA1 and BRCA2).

Diabetes (Option C) is a chronic condition where the body can't properly regulate blood sugar. Type 1 is insulin deficiency due to an autoimmune response, while Type 2 is caused by insulin resistance, often linked to obesity. Symptoms include thirst, frequent urination, and fatigue. Treatment involves lifestyle changes and medication, with long-term risks to organs like the heart and kidneys.


Leukaemia (Option D) is a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, leading to the abnormal production of white blood cells. It is classified into acute and chronic forms, with acute leukaemia progressing rapidly and chronic leukaemia developing more slowly. Symptoms include fatigue, fever, frequent infections, easy bruising, and weight loss.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hairy cell

Explanation:

  • The given image depicts a Hairy cell, which is characterised by the presence of fine, hair-like projections on the surface of the cell.
  • It is a characteristic type of cell found in Hairy Cell Leukemia, which involves abnormal proliferation of Mature B cells.
  • These cells have a round, oblong, or reniform nucleus and pale blue cytoplasm.

Gaucher cells (Option B) are lipid-laden macrophages found in Gaucher's disease, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the GBA1 gene, resulting in deficient glucocerebrosidase enzyme activity. These cells appear as foamy macrophages with a crumpled tissue-paper appearance due to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in the cytoplasm.

Crinkled paper macrophages in the marrow space

Sickle cells (Option C) are abnormally shaped red blood cells that resemble a crescent or sickle due to the presence of abnormal haemoglobin (haemoglobin S). These cells are not characterized by cytoplasmic projections like hairy cells.

Target cells (Option D) are red blood cells that have a bull's-eye appearance due to an increase in cell membrane relative to the volume of the cytoplasm. This condition can occur in several disorders, such as thalassemia, but they do not have the cytoplasmic projections seen in hairy cells.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with easy fatigability, back pain, and multiple lytic lesions in the skull. The bone marrow biopsy finding is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Multiple Myeloma

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of easy fatigability, back pain, and skull lytic lesions, along with Russell bodies in bone marrow biopsy, strongly suggests multiple myeloma, which commonly causes bone pain and elevated serum proteins.

Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells, which normally produce antibodies to fight infections. In this disease, malignant plasma cells proliferate uncontrollably in the bone marrow, crowding out healthy blood cells and producing abnormal proteins that cause complications. Early symptoms may be absent, but when present, they include:

  • Bone pain, especially in the spine or chest
  • Nausea
  • Constipation
  • Loss of appetite
  • Confusion or mental fogginess
  • Fatigue
  • Frequent infections
  • Weight loss
  • Weakness or numbness in the legs
  • Excessive thirst

 

CML (Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia) (Option A) is a blood and bone marrow cancer that leads to an overproduction of white blood cells. In its chronic phase, the disease can often go unnoticed until detected by a blood test. Symptoms include:

  • Weakness
  • Fatigue
  • Shortness of breath with daily activities
  • Fever
  • Bone pain
  • Unexplained weight loss
  • Pain or fullness in the left side of the abdomen due to an enlarged spleen
  • Night sweats

 

CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia) (Option B) is a slow-progressing blood and bone marrow cancer, typically occurring in older adults. It may not cause symptoms in the early stages and is often discovered during a routine blood test. Later symptoms include:

  • Painless swelling of lymph nodes
  • Weakness or fatigue
  • Feeling full due to spleen or liver enlargement
  • Fever and frequent infections
  • Easy bruising or bleeding
  • Unexplained weight loss
  • Drenching night sweats

 

Hairy Cell Leukemia (Option D) is a cancer of the B lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). The leukaemia cells in this condition look "hairy" under a microscope. Symptoms may be absent or include:

  • A feeling of fullness in the abdomen, making it difficult to eat large meals
  • Fatigue
  • Easy bruising
  • Frequent infections
  • Weakness
  • Unintentional weight loss

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with fever, night sweats, and pleural effusion. On further investigation, he is diagnosed with Primary Effusion Lymphoma. What is the most likely causative agent responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus 8):

  • This is the most likely causative agent responsible for Primary Effusion Lymphoma (PEL), a rare and aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. PEL primarily affects immunocompromised individuals, such as those with advanced HIV infection. HHV-8 is also known as Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) and is strongly associated with both Kaposi's sarcoma and Primary Effusion Lymphoma

Incorrect Options:

Option B - EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): Epstein-Barr virus is associated with several types of lymphomas, including Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, and some cases of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. However, it is not typically associated with Primary Effusion Lymphoma.

Option C - HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Human Papillomavirus is known to cause cervical cancer and is not associated with Primary Effusion Lymphoma.

Option D -  HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus): While HIV infection can lead to immunosuppression and an increased risk of certain infections and cancers, including Primary Effusion Lymphoma, it is not the direct causative agent. The underlying infection in this case would be HHV-8.

questions.text: What further test should be conducted for a 60-year-old male patient who has presented with widespread lymph node enlargement, elevated white blood cell count, and smudge cells observed on peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Flow cytometry from peripheral blood

Explanation:

  • The given clinical presentation of a 60-year-old male with lymph node enlargement, elevated WBC, and smudge cells (characteristic cells) on the peripheral smear strongly suggests Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL).
  • Flow cytometry is a highly sensitive technique used to identify the specific cell surface markers on the abnormal lymphocytes in CLL.
  • It helps distinguish CLL from other types of lymphoma and leukaemia.
  • Flow cytometry markers of CLL include CD 5+, CD10-, CD19+, CD20+, CD 23+ and CD 200+


Cytogenic studies (Option A), including Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization

  • (FISH), are helpful in identifying specific genetic mutations associated with CLL, which have prognostic implications. However, flow cytometry is a more immediate and critical step for diagnosis, as it directly assesses the immunophenotype of the cells.

Bone marrow biopsy (Option B) might be performed later to evaluate marrow involvement or disease progression, but it is not the first-line investigation for CLL. Given the peripheral smear findings, Flow cytometry helps to assess the immunophenotype of the lymphocytes.

X-ray crystallography (Option D) is a technique used to determine the atomic and molecular structure of crystals. It is irrelevant in the context of diagnosing CLL.

questions.text: An African child is found to have a mass in the jaw. A biopsy of the mass was done, and it appears as shown in the image below. The child also has a translocation, t(8;14). What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Burkitt lymphoma

Explanation:

The "starry sky" appearance and t(8;14) translocation are characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma, a high-grade B-cell lymphoma. The translocation involves the MYC gene on chromosome 8, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation.

  • All forms of Burkitt’s lymphoma (Endemic, Sporadic, and HIV associated) are associated with such translocations.
  • The most common translocations are t (8:2), t(8:14), and t(8:22)
  • Burkitt's lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma associated with the translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8, t(8:14).
  • It has three primary subtypes:
    1. Endemic Burkitt's lymphoma: Commonly affects children in malaria-endemic areas of Africa, often presenting with tumours in the jaw or facial bones.
    2. Sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma: More frequently seen in non-endemic regions and usually involving the ileocaecal region and peritoneum.
    3. Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma: Found in patients with conditions such as HIV/AIDS or other forms of immunodeficiency.

questions.text: An elderly male presents for a routine medical examination. Laboratory investigations reveal a very high total leukocyte count (TLC). The peripheral smear shows findings as shown in the image. What is the appropriate next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Flow cytometry

Explanation:

  • An elderly male with a high total leukocyte count (TLC) and the presence of smudge cells on the peripheral smear is likely to have Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL). The next appropriate step for confirming the diagnosis is flow cytometry, which analyses cell surface markers and helps identify abnormal lymphocytes characteristic of CLL.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia

Genetics: Trisomy 12, deletion 13q14, and others

Origin: Post–germinal centre memory B cell or naive B Cells in the mantle zone of the lymph node.

Etiopathogenesis

  • Antiapoptotic protein BCL2 overexpression.
  • CLL cell growth depends on Bruton Tyrosine kinase (BTK) activity.
  • No association with radiation exposure

Clinical Presentation

  • Most common Leukemia in the elderly.
  • Frequently asymptomatic at diagnosis.
  • May present with fatigue, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, or infection due to immunosuppression.
  • Associated with autoimmune hemolytic anemia- spherocytes can be seen on peripheral smear
  • Can l/t Hypogammaglobulinemia( highlight )as B cells are abnormal -
  • Infection is the M/C/C of death in CLL

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • Absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) > 5000/mm3
  • Bone marrow lymphocytes >30%
  • Surface markers using flow cytometry were positive for CD5, CD23, CD19, and CD20.
    • CLL co-expresses both T cell (CD5) and B cell (CD20, CD19) markers

Incorrect Options:

Stem cell transplantation (Option A): This is not the first-line treatment for CLL. It is typically considered in more advanced or refractory cases, but the initial approach for most patients involves observation or targeted therapy.

Bone marrow biopsy (Option B): Although bone marrow biopsy can help in finding the extent of infiltration., it is not the first choice for diagnosing CLL. Flow cytometry usually confirms the diagnosis, which is more specific for CLL.

High-dose chemotherapy (Option D) is generally not the first treatment for CLL. Most patients with early-stage CLL are observed without immediate chemotherapy. Treatment is usually initiated if there are symptoms or complications and targeted therapies are often used instead of high-dose chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with low haemoglobin, a platelet count of 25,000/mL, gum bleeding, and raised PT and aPTT. The image of his peripheral smear is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) AML with t(15;17)

Explanation:

  • AML with t(15;17) is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APML), which typically presents with Auer rods on the peripheral smear. The patient also exhibits typical features like low haemoglobin, low platelet count, gum bleeding, and prolonged PT and aPTT, which are seen in this condition due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

M3 AML/ Acute promyelocytic leukaemia:

  • Genetics:
    • t(15:17) translocation causes PML-RARA (retinoic acid receptor alpha) fusion protein formation.
    • Blocks promyelocyte → myelocyte maturation.
    • Diagnosis of choice: Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH)
  • Smear findings:
    • Increased promyelocytes.
    • Auer Rods: Fused granules in promyelocytes
    • Faggot Cells: Auer rods with a crisscross pattern.
  • Laboratory:
    • Low haemoglobin and platelets.
    • > 20% blasts on peripheral and bone marrow smear
    • Stain: PAS +
    • CD markers: CD 13, 33 +
  • Complication: Disseminated intravascular coagulation therefore, chemotherapy is not recommended.
  • Treatment:
    • ATRA (All-trans-retinoic-acid) + As2O3 (arsenic trioxide)
    • Best prognosis among all AML.

FAB classification of AML

Subtype

Name

Features

AML-M0

AML undifferentiated
  • MPO negative

AML-M1

AML without maturation
  • MPO +

AML-M2

AML with maturation
  • Most common
  • t(8:21) RUNX1-RUNX1T1 fusion
  • Associated with chloroma.

AML-M3

Acute promyelocytic leukemia
  • t(15:17) - PML-RAR𝛼 fusion
  • Blocks promyelocyte → myelocyte transformation.
  • Bone marrow: Auer rods form criss-cross called faggot cell.
  • Can cause disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • PAS+

AML-M4

Acute myelomonocytic leukemia
(Option C)
  • Associated with inv 16 and CBF-MYH fusion gene
  • Gums: Gum hypertrophy
  • Skin: Leukaemia cutis
  • MPO+, NSE +

AML-M5

Acute monocytic leukemia
  • Gums: Gum hypertrophy
  • Skin: Leukaemia cutis
  • MPO-, NSE +

AML-M6

Acute erythroid leukemia
  • Also called Di Guglielmo Disease
  • Diffuse PAS+, cd71

AML-M7

Acute megakaryocytic leukemia
  • Bone Marrow aspiration gives a dry tap
  • PAS+, cd41 and cd61

questions.text: Which of the following leukaemias is associated with the given peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear showing an increased number of small, mature lymphocytes with a characteristic smudge appearance is indicative of Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL).

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL): (Option A)

 
  • Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolations
  • They contain fat (Oil Red O Positive)
  • Hand mirror-shaped cells

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) (Option C)

  • Blasts ≥ 20%
  • Myeloblasts with Auer rods

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL):

  • Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cell): Due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation
  • Convent Girl Appearance: Lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) (Option D)

  • Leukocytosis
  • Cell Types: Neutrophils( multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

questions.text: Identify the cell in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Mast cell

Explanation:

  • The given image shows mast cells stained with toluidine blue. It contains the acid proteoglycan that binds basic blue.
  • Mast cells are characterized by the presence of large granules & stains with toluidine blue, giving them a distinct purple-blue colour. It plays a crucial role in allergic reactions and inflammation by releasing histamine and other mediators from their granules.

 

Macrophages (Option B) are large phagocytic cells with abundant cytoplasm and a kidney-shaped nucleus. They lack metachromatic granules and do not stain with toluidine blue.

Plasma cells (Option C) have an eccentric nucleus with a clock-face chromatin pattern and a perinuclear hof due to the prominent Golgi apparatus; they produce antibodies but lack granules.

Fibroblasts (Option D) are spindle-shaped cells involved in collagen and extracellular matrix synthesis, lacking granules and immune functions. Histopathologically, they appear as elongated, fusiform cells with a pale, slightly granular cytoplasm and a single, elongated nucleus.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents with fatigue for the past year. Examination reveals massive splenomegaly. His blood workup shows the following findings:


	Anemia
	Total leukocyte count (TLC): 150,000/microliter
	Peripheral smear: 60% neutrophils, 6% basophils, 4% eosinophils, myeloblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes
	Myeloid to erythroid ratio: 18:1


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)

Explanation:

Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML) is the most likely diagnosis due to:

  • Massive splenomegaly, which is a hallmark of CML.
  • Marked leukocytosis (TLC of 150,000/microliter) with a predominance of neutrophils and the presence of immature myeloid cells (myeloblasts, myelocytes, metamyelocytes) on the peripheral smear. These are key features of CML.
