  • Basophilia (6%) and the myeloid-to-erythroid ratio of 18:1, characteristic of CML, further support this diagnosis.

 

Here is the revised table:

Aspect

Details

Genetics

Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22))

Origin

Myeloid lineage

Etiopathogenesis

BCR-ABL fusion gene causes overactive tyrosine kinase activity and is associated with radiation exposure.

Clinical Features
  • Common in adults, presenting with splenomegaly, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort.
  • It can progress to a blast crisis with acute leukaemia features.

Diagnosis
  • Bone marrow aspirate to confirm diagnosis
  • FISH to detect BCR-ABL fusion gene product

Management

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., Imatinib)

 

The 3 phases of CML and their characteristics are:

1) Chronic phase:
  • Leukocytosis, < 10% blast cells, basophils <20% and monocytosis < 3%

2) Accelerated phase:
  • 10%-19% blasts, ≥ 20% basophils in the peripheral blood or bone marrow
  • Persistent or increasing WBC (>10 × 10^9/L) and splenomegaly, unresponsive to therapy
  • Persistent thrombocytosis (>1000 × 10^9/L), unresponsive to therapy
  • Persistent thrombocytopenia (<100 × 10^9/L) unrelated to therapy
  • This phase often leads to the terminal blast crisis within 6-12 months.

3) Blast Crisis:
  • ≥20% blasts in peripheral blood or bone marrow
  • In 50% of patients, the blast crisis occurs abruptly without an accelerated phase.
  • Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis occurs to compensate for CML and leads to significant splenomegaly.
  • Transformation into AML is more predominant than ALL.

 

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

 

  • Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolations
  • They contain fat (Oil Red O Positive)
  • Hand mirror-shaped cells

 

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

  • Blasts ≥ 20%
  • Myeloblasts with AuerRods

 

3. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL):

  • Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cell): Due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation
  • Convent Girl Appearance: Lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

  • Leukocytosis
  • Cell Types: Neutrophils( multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

questions.text: What is the most accurate test for evaluating the effectiveness of treatment in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) RT PCR

Explanation:

RT-PCR is the most sensitive test for monitoring treatment response in chronic myeloid leukemía (CML).

  • It accurately detects and quantifies the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, allowing for precise assessment of treatment response and minimal residual disease (MRD) status in CML patients.
  • Regular monitoring with RT-PCR guides treatment decisions for optimal patient outcomes.

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia:

  • It occurs due to the translocation of Philadelphia chromosome t (9:22) (q34.1, q11.2).
  • BCR-ALB1 is a hybrid gene. It is a translocation with respect to the long arm of chromosome no. 9 to the long arm of chromosome no. 22
  • BCR: Breakpoint cluster region
  • ALB1: Abelson leukemia
  • BCR-ALB1 results in the production of novel oncoproteins (Molecular weight: 210 kilodaltons)

 

CBC (Complete Blood Count) (Option A): While CBC indicates changes in blood cell levels, it may not detect MRD or early treatment failure as sensitively as RT-PCR.

Cytogenetic Test (Option B): Although cytogenetic tests reveal chromosomal abnormalities like the Philadelphia chromosome, they may not detect low levels of disease or MRD as effectively as molecular techniques like RT-PCR.

FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) (Option D): While FISH detects genetic sequences like the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, it may not quantify residual disease or assess treatment response as accurately as RT-PCR.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old boy who has weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in his jaw area, with anaemia and lymphocytosis revealed by a CBC and biopsy findings shown in the accompanying image?\
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Burkitt’s lymphoma

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of weight loss, fever, painless jaw swelling, along with a starry sky appearance on histology and anaemia with lymphocytosis on CBC, strongly suggests Burkitt’s lymphoma.

  • It is an aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, typically associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, HIV, and chromosomal translocations leading to c-myc oncogene overexpression.
  • It is classified into three clinical groups: endemic, sporadic, and immunodeficiency-related.
  • Clinical symptoms include:
    • Painless swelling: The most common symptom is the presence of one or more painless, rapidly enlarging masses, typically involving lymph nodes.
    • Heavy night sweating
    • Intermittent high fever
    • Significant weight loss (more than 10% of body weight)
  • Associated with the translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8, t(8:14).
  • It has three primary subtypes:
    • Endemic Burkitt's lymphoma: Commonly affects children in malaria-endemic areas of Africa, often presenting with tumours in the jaw or facial bones.
    • Sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma: More frequently seen in non-endemic regions and usually involving the ileocaecal region and peritoneum
    • Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma: Found in patients with conditions such as HIV/AIDS or other forms of immunodeficiency.

 

Hodgkin's disease (Option A) is a cancer of the lymphatic system, characterised by uncontrolled proliferation of lymphocytes. It often presents with painless swollen lymph nodes, but the hallmark feature is the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells (large, abnormal lymphocytes with two nuclei resembling "owl eyes"). HL is treated with chemotherapy, radiation, and stem-cell transplantation.

 

Acute lymphocytic leukaemia (ALL) (Option B) is a malignancy of the blood and bone marrow characterised by the rapid production of immature white blood cells. Common symptoms include fatigue, pallor, frequent infections, and unusual bleeding, but it does not typically present with localised swelling, as seen in Burkitt’s lymphoma.

 

Chloroma (Option C), also known as granulocytic sarcoma or myeloid sarcoma, is a rare tumour composed of myeloblasts, usually associated with acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). It can form in various tissues such as the bones, skin, lymph nodes, and central nervous system, but it does not present with the distinctive symptoms or patterns of Burkitt's lymphoma, such as the characteristic jaw swelling. Chloromas are often nonspecific and can include symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, and pain.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with bleeding gums for 20 days. He has gingival hyperplasia and hepatosplenomegaly. On investigation, Hb-11 g/dL, platelet count-95,000 platelets/mm3, and WBC count-45000 cells/mm3. A bone marrow biopsy shows 100% cellularity, with many blast cells that are peroxidase-negative and non-specific esterase-positive. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Acute myeloid leukemia M5 (AML M5):

  • The patient's presentation with bleeding gums, gingival hyperplasia, hepatosplenomegaly, and bone marrow biopsy findings, which indicate 100% cellularity with many blast cells that are peroxidase negative and non-specific esterase positive, is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia M5 (AML M5).
  • Acute myeloid leukemia M5 (AML M5) is also known as acute monocytic leukemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute Myeloid Leukemia M2 (AML M2): It is characterized by the presence of abnormal promyelocytes in the bone marrow and blood.

Option B - Acute Myeloid Leukemia M0 (AML M0): It is characterized by the absence of surface markers on the blast cells.

Option D - Acute Myeloid Leukemia M7 (AML M7): It is characterized by the presence of abnormal megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, which can lead to thrombocytopenia and bleeding.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of agranulocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Drug toxicity:

  • The most common cause of agranulocytosis is drug toxicity.
  • Agranulocytosis refers to a severe decrease in the number of granulocytes in the blood.
  • Various medications, such as certain antibiotics (e.g., penicillin, sulfonamides), antithyroid drugs (e.g., propylthiouracil, methimazole), anticonvulsants (e.g., carbamazepine), and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), can cause agranulocytosis as a rare adverse reaction.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are not the most common cause of agranulocytosis.

questions.text: Mononuclear Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lymphocyte-rich HL:

  • Mononuclear Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are characteristic cells seen in the lymphocyte-rich subtype of HL.

Incorrect Options:

  • Mononuclear Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are not seen in Options A, B, and D.
